meta-review.comment:
Hippo Penny -

Alright, let's dive into the review of Lords of the Fallen. I'm not going to sugarcoat it; this game is a soulslike that's got some serious competition with itself. Okay, maybe not exactly like itself... more like it's trying to be its own unique snowflake in a blizzard of similar games.

The game's biggest strength lies in its world design. The areas you get to explore are vast, atmospheric, and downright gorgeous. It's like stepping into an Edgar Allan Poe painting come to life - dark, mysterious, and full of hidden secrets. I mean, who doesn't love discovering a new, ancient ruin or fighting off hordes of ghouls in a creepy cave?

Now, about that unique twist: swapping between two versions of the world? It's actually pretty brilliant! Imagine being able to switch between day and night modes to solve puzzles or sneak past enemies. It adds an extra layer of depth to exploration and combat, making you think creatively about how to approach situations.

On the other hand, when it comes to boss fights... let's just say I've seen more exciting battles at a kindergarten playground. They're either too easy or too frustratingly hard. Maybe it's just me being impatient, but those battles can get pretty grueling - not in a "Oh, this is so challenging and rewarding!" kind of way, more like "Why am I still fighting this stupid dragon again?"

Technical issues? Yeah, they're there, folks! I mean, we all know that Soulsborne games are notorious for their performance problems. It's almost like they come with an added layer of difficulty - you have to navigate not only the game's mechanics but also its glitches and framerate hiccups.

What does this mean for us players? Well, if you're a fan of action RPGs and don't mind a few (or many) technical hiccups, Lords of the Fallen might be worth your time. Just keep in mind that it's not perfect - yet! With some more polish and refinement, this game could truly shine.

Hippo Penny out!
